brief_summary.textblock: Evaluation and comparison of histological analysis, 9,4 tesla MRI, Full-Field Optical Coherence Tomography (FFOCT) and ultrasound-based navigation system for cartilage degeneration analysis of patellofemoral joint.

detailed_description.textblock: Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a common and debilitating chronic degenerative disease of the articular cartilage. Despite recent progress in the field of cartilage imaging, no routinely used clinical imaging modality has the ability to evaluate and monitor changes in cartilage degeneration. This observationnal, pilot, prospective, non randomized, uncontrolled, monocentric study aim to compare three of the most innovative imaging systems, namely the 9,4 Tesla MRI, the FFOCT (Full-Field Optical Coherence Tomography) and the ultrasound-based navigation system in order to image healthly to severely degraded human cartilage samples. All methods will be cross-correlated and compared with histological data considered as the gold standard.

arm_group.description: All subject of the study have a knee osteoarthritis (OA) and are going to have a knee prosthetic surgery with cartilage excision. Multimodal evaluation is conducted on ex vivo human cartilage samples (2 samples per patient are selected : healthy and severely degraded).

biospec_descr.textblock: cartilage samples undergoing total knee arthroplasty procedure

study_pop.textblock: Patients with knee arthroplasty indication for medial femoro-tibial osteoarthristis at University Hospital, Grenoble
